Author: stellerooti

Comment: As a POC who served, serving can feel like a real privilege/honor. I wish more people could experience it. Not everyone in the country is an asshole, and even those who are still assholes are still Americans at the end of the day. After serving, I look at everyday folks on the street a bit differently now.  I give a little more grace than I used to. Don't get me wrong, it's a slap in the face when some people don't see you as a "real American" simply based off of what I look like, despite serving for half a decade and having ancestors that have been here for centuries.   It can also open so many doors (GI Bill, professional experience, world travel at a young age, a way to get out of a shitty hometown, etc.).
Author: my_Urban_Sombrero

Comment: You shouldnt have to sell your soul to the government for basic necessities
Author: elexexexex2

Comment: Honestly, my life would have benefited from some kind of structure in my early twenties, and that has made me think a year or two of conscription for youngins might do us some good
Author: lingbabana

Comment: I don’t disagree there. The whole experience did turn me onto the idea of a robust welfare state, though.  Like I entered the service as an enlightened centrist and came out a militant leftist lol.

Comment: That's interesting!  I would have thought things tended toward the other direction for people.
Author: Elseiver

Comment: There was a certain peace of mind given by a guaranteed roof over my head, healthcare, and never worrying about where my next meal came from that I do miss. In my free time I pursued hobbies, took some online classes (finished my B.A.!), saved up for fun things (a wedding/honeymoon). It was a vibe, but I didn't want to make it a career.   Now I'm in grad school and house poor, but thriving otherwise!
Author: my_Urban_Sombrero
